question_text: How do nanosecond pulsed discharges generate gas-dynamic perturbations that enhance flame stabilization in lean combustors, and what is the role of fast gas heating in this process?
standard_answer: Nanosecond pulsed discharges enhance flame stabilization in lean combustors by generating gas-dynamic perturbations through rapid localized heating from fast gas heating. Each discharge pulse produces FGH on timescales shorter than acoustic times (e.g., nanoseconds), creating pressure waves and weak shock waves that propagate through the flow. These perturbations interact with shear layers and flame fronts, promoting mixing and recirculation of hot products, which stabilizes flames by maintaining reactive zones in recirculation regions. Specifically, in swirl burners, FGH-induced compression waves excite instabilities that form coherent vortices, enhancing fuel-air mixing and reducing blow-off limits. The role of FGH is critical as it provides the thermal energy release that drives these gas-dynamic effects; for example, temperature rises of hundreds of kelvins in discharge channels lead to rapid expansion and wave generation. This is combined with radical production from plasma, which sustains combustion chemistry in lean conditions. Experimental studies show that pulsed nanosecond discharges with power less than 1% of flame power can significantly lower lean blow-off limits, demonstrating how FGH-driven perturbations overcome the slow flame propagation in ultra-lean mixtures by dynamically altering flow structures and reaction zones.

original_text.1: In particular case of pulse-periodic nanosecond discharges, fast heat release in each pulse causes gas-dynamic perturbations.
